content.title: Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS)
content.summary: Endoscopic ultrasound combines endoscopy with high-frequency ultrasonography to obtain detailed images of the GI tract wall layers and adjacent structures. It is invaluable for staging GI malignancies, evaluating pancreaticobiliary disease, characterizing submucosal lesions, and performing fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of lesions inaccessible to other techniques.
key_points: Combines endoscope with ultrasound transducer at tip (radial or linear array)
Best modality for T-staging esophageal, gastric, rectal, and pancreatic cancers
Superior to CT for detecting small pancreatic masses and chronic pancreatitis
EUS-FNA: Tissue acquisition from pancreatic masses, lymph nodes, liver lesions
Therapeutic applications: celiac plexus block, pancreatic cyst drainage, biliary access
Wall layers: mucosa (1&2), submucosa (3), muscularis propria (4), serosa/adventitia (5)
content.statement: EUS provides high-resolution imaging of GI wall layers and adjacent structures for cancer staging and characterization of submucosal lesions, with the added capability of tissue acquisition and therapeutic interventions.

explanation.intuition: Think of EUS as putting an ultrasound probe right next to the area of interest from inside the GI tract. Just as an obstetrician gets better images with a transvaginal ultrasound than abdominal, the endosonographer gets exquisitely detailed images by placing the probe millimeters from the target instead of imaging through skin, fat, and bowel gas.
explanation.key_insight: EUS excels in two scenarios: (1) determining how deep a tumor invades (T-stage) because it can distinguish individual wall layers, and (2) accessing lesions that are difficult to biopsy externally, like a pancreatic mass behind the stomach. The ability to biopsy under real-time guidance while avoiding blood vessels is a major advantage.
explanation.technical_details: Radial EUS provides 360° cross-sectional view (like CT slice) for orientation and staging. Linear EUS provides sagittal view in line with scope for FNA guidance. Frequencies 5-12 MHz; higher = better resolution but less penetration. Normal wall layers: hypoechoic/hyperechoic pattern from lumen outward.

definitions_glossary.EUS: Endoscopic ultrasound - combining endoscopy with ultrasonography
definitions_glossary.radial_EUS: 360° cross-sectional imaging perpendicular to endoscope axis
definitions_glossary.linear_EUS: Sagittal imaging parallel to scope; allows FNA
definitions_glossary.EUS_FNB: EUS-guided fine-needle biopsy using core needle for histology
definitions_glossary.T_staging: Tumor depth staging; EUS is gold standard for wall layer involvement
definitions_glossary.submucosal_lesion: Lesion arising from or below mucosa (GIST, leiomyoma, lipoma)
definitions_glossary.muscularis_propria: Fourth hypoechoic layer; GIST typically arises here
definitions_glossary.celiac_plexus_block: EUS-guided injection of anesthetic/alcohol for pain control
definitions_glossary.mediastinal_lymph_node: Accessible via esophageal EUS for staging lung/esophageal cancer
definitions_glossary.pancreatic_cyst: Fluid collection evaluated and drained via EUS
definitions_glossary.echoendoscope: Specialized endoscope with ultrasound transducer at tip

pathophysiology.mechanism: High-frequency ultrasound transducer at endoscope tip provides high-resolution imaging of GI wall layers and adjacent structures without interference from bowel gas or body habitus

transducer_types.radial: 360° view, excellent for orientation and staging, no FNA capability in most
transducer_types.linear: Sagittal view in line with needle path, required for FNA/FNB
transducer_types.miniprobe: Through-the-scope catheter probe for superficial lesions

advantages_over_CT: Superior detection of small pancreatic tumors (<2cm)

diagnostic_procedures: EUS-FNA of pancreatic masses (85-95% sensitivity for malignancy)

therapeutic_applications.pain_management: Celiac plexus neurolysis for pancreatic cancer pain
therapeutic_applications.biliary_access: EUS-guided biliary drainage when ERCP fails

complications: Infection (rare; prophylactic antibiotics for cyst aspiration)

definition.@value: An endoscopic procedure combining visualization with high-frequency ultrasonography to image GI wall layers and adjacent structures, with capability for tissue acquisition

scopeNote.@value: Covers technique, indications, diagnostic and therapeutic applications of EUS

learning_objectives: Describe the components and types of endoscopic ultrasound
Identify the five sonographic layers of the GI wall
List indications for EUS in cancer staging
Compare radial vs linear EUS capabilities
Explain EUS-FNA technique and diagnostic yield
clinical_pearls: EUS is gold standard for T-staging esophageal, gastric, and rectal cancer
Linear EUS required for FNA - radial cannot guide needle
Pancreatic mass FNA: 85-95% sensitivity with negative predictive value caveat
GIST arises from 4th layer (muscularis propria) - hypoechoic on EUS
EUS superior to CT for chronic pancreatitis diagnosis (Rosemont criteria)
common_misconceptions: EUS can detect distant metastases - limited to local/regional structures
All submucosal lesions need FNA - many can be characterized by EUS features alone
Negative EUS-FNA rules out malignancy - false negatives occur, repeat sampling may be needed
